question: Consider the state space realization $\begin{bmatrix} x_{1}(t)\\ x_{2}(t) \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 0\\ 0&-9 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x_{1}(t)\\ x_{2}(t) \end{bmatrix}+ \begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 45 \end{bmatrix}u(t)$ , with the initial condition $\begin{bmatrix} x_{1}(0)\\ x_{2}(0) \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 0 \end{bmatrix}$ where u(t) denotes the unit step function. The value of  $\lim_{t\rightarrow \infty }|\sqrt{x_{1}^{2}(t)+x_{2}^{2}(t)}|$  is _______.
explanation: Question 8  Explanation: $\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{l} \dot{x}_{1}(t) \\ \dot{x}_{2}(t) \end{array}\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{cc} 0 & 0 \\ 0 & -9 \end{array}\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{l} x_{1}(t) \\ x_{2}(t) \end{array}\end{bmatrix}+\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{c} 0 \\ 45 \end{array}\end{bmatrix} u(t)$ By applying Laplace transform on both sides. get $ \begin{aligned} s x_{1}(s)-x_{1}(0)&=0\\ X_{1}(s)&=\frac{x_{1}(0)}{s}=0 \quad \because x_{1}(0)=0 \\ \text{So,} x_{1}(t)&=0 \\ \text{and }\quad s X_{\lambda}(s)-x_{2}(0)&=-9 X_{1}(s)+\frac{45}{s} \\ X_{2}(s) &=\frac{45}{s(s+9)} \quad \because x_{2}(0)=0 \\ \text { Required value } &=\lim _{t \rightarrow \infty}|\sqrt{x_{1}^{2}(t)+x_{2}^{2}(t)}| \\ &=\left|\lim _{t \rightarrow \infty} x_{2}(t)\right| \quad \because x_{1}(t)=0 \\ \lim _{t \rightarrow \infty} x_{2}(t) &=\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} s X_{2}(s)=\frac{45}{9}=5 \end{aligned}$ So, Required value $= |5| =5$

explanation: Question 10  Explanation: State matrix form: $ \begin{array}{l} \dot{x}=\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{cc} 2 & -1 \\ 0 & -4 \end{array}\end{bmatrix} x+\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{c} 3 \\ -1 \end{array}\end{bmatrix} u \\ y=\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{ll} 3 & -2 \end{array}\end{bmatrix} x \end{array}$ The transfer function from tate matrix can be calculated as: $ T(S)=C(s l-A]^{-1} B+D$ Here, $ [s l-A]^{-1}=\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{cc} s-2 & 1 \\ 0 & s+4 \end{array}\end{bmatrix}^{-1}$ $\begin{aligned} &=\frac{1}{(s-2)(s+4)}\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{cc} (s+4) & -1 \\ 0 & (s-2) \end{array}\end{bmatrix} \\ \Rightarrow &C[s /-A]^{-1} B \\ =& \frac{1}{(s-2)(s+4)}[3-2]\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{cc} (s+4) & -1 \\ 0 & (s-2) \end{array}\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{c} 3 \\ -1 \end{array}\end{bmatrix} \\ =& \frac{1}{(s-2)(s+4)}[3-2]\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{c} 3 s+12+1 \\ -s+2 \end{array}\end{bmatrix} \\ =& \frac{1}{(s-2)(s+4)}[9 s+39+2 s-4] \\ =& \frac{11 s+35}{(s-2)(s+4)} \end{aligned}$

explanation: Question 11  Explanation: The response of the system is given by $ x(t)=L^{-1}\begin{bmatrix}(s l-A)^{-1} x(0)+(s /-A)^{-1} B \cdot U(s)\end{bmatrix} $ and the complete response $ y(t)=[C] x(t) $ From the given state model, $ \begin{array}{l} A=\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{ll}0 & 1 \\ 0 & -1\end{array}\end{bmatrix} ; B=0: C=[0 \quad 1] \; and \;  x(0)=\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{c}1 \\ 0\end{array}\end{bmatrix} \\ \therefore \quad(s l-A)^{-1}=\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{cc}s & -1 \\ 0 & s+1\end{array}\end{bmatrix}^{-1} \\ =\frac{1}{s(s+1)}\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{cc}s+1 & 1 \\ 0 & s\end{array}\end{bmatrix} \\ (s l-A)^{-1} x(0)=\frac{1}{s(s+1)}\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{cc} s+1 & 1 \\ 0 & s \end{array}\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 0 \end{array}\end{bmatrix} \\ =\frac{1}{s(s+1)}\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{c} s+1 \\ 0 \end{array}\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{c} 1 / s \\ 0 \end{array}\end{bmatrix} \\ \Rightarrow x(t)=L^{-1}\begin{bmatrix}(s I-A)^{-1} x(0)\end{bmatrix} \\ =\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 0 \end{array}\end{bmatrix} u(t) \end{array}$ and the complete response $ y(t)=\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{lll}0 & 1\end{array}\end{bmatrix} x(t)=\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{ll}0 & 1\end{array}\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 0\end{array}\end{bmatrix}=0$

explanation: Question 12  Explanation: $\begin{aligned} \text { Given } &\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{l} \dot{x}_{1} \\ \dot{x}_{2} \end{array}\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{ll} 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 \end{array}\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{l} x_{1} \\ x_{2} \end{array}\end{bmatrix} \\ A &=\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{ll} 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 \end{array}\end{bmatrix} \\ [s I-A] &=\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{ll} s & 0 \\ 0 & s \end{array}\end{bmatrix}-\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{ll} 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 \end{array}\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{ll} s & -1 \\ 0 & s \end{array}\end{bmatrix} \\ [s I-A]=s^{2} & \\ \phi(t) &=\mathcal{L}^{-1}[s I-A]^{-1} \\ &=\frac{1}{s^{2}}\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{ll} s & 1 \\ 0 & s \end{array}\end{bmatrix} \\ &=L^{-1}\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{cc} \frac{1}{s} & \frac{1}{s^{2}} \\ 0 & \frac{1}{s} \end{array}\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{ll} 1 & t \\ 0 & 1 \end{array}\end{bmatrix} \end{aligned}$

question: The state equation of a second-order linear system is given by $\dot{x}(t) = Ax(t), \;\; x(0) = x_{0}$ For  $x_{0}=\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ -1 \end{bmatrix}, \; x(t)=\begin{bmatrix} e^{-t}\\ -e^{-t} \end{bmatrix}$ and  for $ x_{0}=\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix},$ $ x(t)=\begin{bmatrix} e^{-t}-e^{-2t}\\ -e^{-t}+2e^{-2t} \end{bmatrix} $ when  $ x_{0}=\begin{bmatrix} 3\\ 5 \end{bmatrix}$, x(t) is
explanation: Question 13  Explanation: Given $\dot{x}(t)=A x(t), \quad x(0)=x_{0} $ Taking the Laplace transform $ \begin{aligned} s X(s)-x(0) &=A X(s) \\ [s I-A] X(s) &=x(0) \\ X(s) &=[s I-A]^{-1} x(0) \\ x(t) &=\mathcal{L}^{-1}[s I-A]^{-1} x(0) &\ldots(i) \end{aligned}$ Condition given are $ \begin{aligned} For x_{0}&=\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{c}1 \\ -1\end{array}\end{bmatrix}, x(t)=\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{c}e^{-t} \\ -e^{-t}\end{array}\end{bmatrix} \\ For x_{0}&=\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{l}0 \\ 1\end{array}\end{bmatrix}, x(t)=\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{l}e^{-t}-e^{-2 t} \\ -e^{-t}+2 e^{-2 t}\end{array}\end{bmatrix} \end{aligned}$ Using the linearity property in equation (i) $ K_{1} x_{1}(t)=\mathcal{L}^{-1}[s I-A]^{-1} x_{1}(0) K_{1} $ $ K_{2} x_{2}(t)=\mathcal{L}^{-1}[s I-A]^{-1} x_{2}(0) K_{2} $ Using the linearity property as $ \begin{aligned} K_{1} x_{1}(t)+K_{2} x_{2}(t)&=\mathcal{L}^{-1}[s I-A]^{-1} \\  \begin{bmatrix}K_{1} x_{1}(0)+K_{2} x_{2}(0)\end{bmatrix} & \quad \ldots(ii)\\ \text { Also } \quad X_{3}(s)&=[s I-A]^{-1} x_{3}(0) \\ \text{So, } \quad K_{1}\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{r}1 \\ -1\end{array}\end{bmatrix}+&K_{2}\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{l}0 \\ 1\end{array}\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{l}3 \\ 5\end{array}\end{bmatrix} \\ \begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{l}K_{1}+O K_{2} \\ -K_{1}+K_{2}\end{array}\end{bmatrix}&=\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{l}3 \\ 5\end{array}\end{bmatrix} \\ \Rightarrow \quad K_{1}&=3 \\ K_{2}&=8 \end{aligned}$ So, from equation (ii), we get x(t) $\begin{aligned} x(t) &=K_{1} x_{1}(t)+K_{2} x_{2}(t) \\ &=3\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{c} e^{-t} \\ -e^{-t} \end{array}\end{bmatrix}+8\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{c} e^{-t}-e^{-2 t} \\ -e^{-t}+2 e^{-2 t} \end{array}\end{bmatrix} \\ &=\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{c} 11 e^{-t}-8 e^{-2 t} \\ -1 t e^{-t}+16 e^{-2 t} \end{array}\end{bmatrix} \end{aligned}$

explanation: Question 15  Explanation: $\begin{aligned}\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{l}\dot{x}_{1} \\ \dot{x}_{2}\end{array}\end{bmatrix} &=\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{cc}-1 & 0 \\ 0 & -2\end{array}\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{l}x_{1} \\ x_{2}\end{array}\end{bmatrix} \\ \dot{x}_{1} &=-x_{1}+0 x_{2} \\ \dot{x}_{2} &=0 x_{1}-2 x_{2} \end{aligned} $ Applying Laplace transform on both equations $ \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow s X_{1}(s)-x_{1}(0)&=-X_{1}(s) \\ X_{1}(s)[s+1]&=X_{1}(0) \quad &\text{given }x_{1}(0)=1 \\ X_{1}(s)&=\frac{1}{s+1} \\ \Rightarrow \quad e^{-t}&=x_{1}(t)\\ \Rightarrow \quad s X_{2}(s)-X_{2}(0)&=-2 X_{2}(s) \\ (s+2) X_{2}(s)&=X_{2}(0) &X_{2}(0)=-1 \\ X_{2}(s)&=-\frac{1}{s+2} \\ x_{2}(t)&=-e^{-2 t} \end{aligned}$

is given as $\begin{bmatrix} \frac{d\omega }{dt}\\ \frac{di_{a}}{dt} \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} -1 & 1\\ -1&-10 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} \omega \\ i_{a} \end{bmatrix}+\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 10 \end{bmatrix}u$ where $\omega$ is the speed of the motor, $i_{a}$ is the armature current and u is the armature voltage. The transfer function $\frac{\omega (s)}{U(s)}$ of the motor is
explanation: Question 28  Explanation: $\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{c}\frac{d \omega}{d t} \\\frac{d i_{a}}{d t}\end{array}\end{bmatrix}&=\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{cc} -1 & 1 \\ -1 & -10 \end{array}\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{l} \omega \\ i_{a} \end{array}\end{bmatrix}+\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{c} 0 \\ 10 \end{array}\end{bmatrix} u\\ \Rightarrow \frac{d \omega}{d t}&=-\omega+i_{\mathrm{a}} &\ldots(i)\\ \Rightarrow \frac{d i_{\mathrm{a}}}{d t}&=-\omega-10 i_{\mathrm{a}}+10 u &\ldots(ii) \end{aligned}$ Taking Laplace transform (i) \& (ii) $ \begin{array}{l} \Rightarrow s \omega(s)=-\omega(s)+I_{a}(s) \\ \Rightarrow(s+1) \omega(s)=I_{a}(s) \quad\ldots(iii)\\ \Rightarrow s I_{e}(s)=-\omega(s)-10 I_{a}(s)+10 U(s) \\ \Rightarrow \omega(s)=(-10-s) I_{a}(s)+10 U(s) \\ =(-10-s)(s+1) \omega(s)+10 U(s) \\ =-\begin{bmatrix}s^{2}+11 s+10\end{bmatrix} \omega(s)+10 U(s) \\ \Rightarrow\begin{bmatrix}s^{2}+11 s+11\end{bmatrix} \omega(s)=10 U(s) \\ \Rightarrow \frac{\omega(s)}{U(s)}=\frac{10}{\left(s^{2}+11 s+11\right)} \end{array}$

explanation: Question 32  Explanation: $\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{c}\dot{x}_{1} \\\dot{x}_{2}\end{array}\end{bmatrix}&=\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{cc}-3 & -1 \\2 & 0\end{array}\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{l}x_{1} \\x_{2}\end{array}\end{bmatrix}+\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{l}1 \\0\end{array}\end{bmatrix} u \\ y&=\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{ll}1 & 0\end{array}\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{l}x_{1} \\x_{2}\end{array}\end{bmatrix}+\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{l}1 \\0\end{array}\end{bmatrix} u \\ Q_{C}&=\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{ll}B & A B\end{array}\end{bmatrix}\\ \end{aligned}$ $\begin{aligned} A B&=\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{c}-3 \\ 2\end{array}\end{bmatrix} \\ \therefore \quad a_{c}&=\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{cc}1 & -3 \\ 0 & 2\end{array}\end{bmatrix} \neq 0 \\ \therefore \text{Controllable } \\ Q_{0}&=\begin{bmatrix}C^{\top} \quad A^{\top} C^{\prime}\end{bmatrix} \\ C^{T}&=\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 0\end{array}\end{bmatrix}, \quad A^{T}&=\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{ll}-3 & 2 \\ -1 & 0\end{array}\end{bmatrix} \\ A^{\top} C^{T}&=\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{l}-3 \\ -1\end{array}\end{bmatrix} \\ \therefore \quad Q_{0}&=\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{ll}1 & -3 \\ 0 & -1\end{array}\end{bmatrix} \neq 0 \\ \therefore \text{ Observable} \end{aligned}$

question:
Consider a unity negative feedback control system with forward path gain $G(s)=\frac{K}{(s+1)(s+2)(s+3)}$ as shown.
The impulse response of the closed-loop system decays faster than $e^{-t}$ if ______
explanation:
Question 1  Explanation: Given, $
G(s)=\frac{K}{(S+1)(S+2)(S+3)}
$ Impulse response of system is $
Y(S)=\frac{K}{(S+1)(S+2)(S+3)+K}
$ Given: At impulse response of closed loop system decay faster than $e^{-t}$ Hence, put $s=s-1$, $\therefore$ The new characteristic equation is, $
\begin{aligned}
& (s-1+1)(s-1+2)(s-1+3)+K=0 \\
& s(s+1)(s+2)+K=0 \\
& s^{3}+3 s^{2}+2 s+K=0
\end{aligned}
$ By $\mathrm{RH}$ criterion, $
\begin{array}{c|cc}
s^{3} & 1 & 2 \\
s^{2} & 3 & K \\
s^{1} & \frac{6-K}{3} & \\
s^{0} & K &
\end{array}
$ $
\therefore K \gt 0 ; \quad \frac{6-K}{3} \gt 0 \Rightarrow K \lt 6
$ $
\therefore \quad 0 \lt K \lt 6
$ Hence, option satisfies above range of $K$.
subject: Control Systems

question:
Consider the following closed loop control system where $G(s)=\frac{1}{s(s+1)}$ and $C(s)=K\frac{s+1}{s+3}$.
If the steady state error for a unit ramp input

explanation: Question 5  Explanation: Open loop transfer function for the system $=C(s)\times G(s)=\frac{K(s+1)}{ (s+3)}\times \frac{1}{s(s+1)}$ Since the system is type-1, so far a given unit ramp input steady state $e_{ss}=\frac{1}{K_{V}} $ where,  $K_{V}=\lim_{s\rightarrow 0}S\times \frac{K}{S(S+3)}=\frac{K}{3} $ so, $\; e_{ss}=\frac{1}{K/3}=\frac{3}{K}$ Given that,  $\; e_{ss}=0.1 $ So, $0.1=\frac{3}{K}\Rightarrow K=30$

question:
A system with transfer function $G(s)=\frac{1}{(s+1)(s+a)}, a \gt 0$ is subjected an input $5\cos 3t$.
The steady state output of the system is $\frac{1}{\sqrt{10}} \cos (3t-1.892)$. The value of $a$ is ____.
explanation: Question 6  Explanation: Given that, $\begin{aligned}G(j\omega )&=\frac{1}{(1+j\omega )(\alpha +j\omega )} \\ \left |G(j\omega ) \right |&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{(\omega ^{2}+1)(\omega ^{2}+\alpha ^{2})}} \\ \text{According to }& \text{question,}\\ \left | G(j\omega ) \right |_{\omega =3}&=\frac{1}{5\sqrt{10}}\\ \Rightarrow \frac{1}{\sqrt{(\omega ^{2}+1)(\omega ^{2}+\alpha ^{2})}}&=\frac{1}{5\sqrt{10}} \\ \Rightarrow \frac{1}{\sqrt{10(a^{2}+9)}}&=\frac{1}{5\sqrt{10}} \alpha ^{2}+9=25 \\ \alpha ^{2}&=16 \\ \alpha &=4\end{aligned}$

question: The loop transfer function of a negative feedback system is $G(s)H(s)=\frac{K(s+11)}{s(s+2)(s+8)}$ The value of K, for which the system is marginally stable, is ________.
explanation: Question 7  Explanation: Characteristic equation q(s) for the given open loop system will be $q(s)=s^{3}+10s^{2}+16s+Ks+11K=0$ Using R-H criteria, For System to be Marginally Stable $\begin{aligned}\frac{10(16+K)-11K}{10}&=0 \\ 160+10K-11K&=0 \\ K&=160\end{aligned}$

question: Consider a causal second-order system with the transfer function $G(s)=\frac{1}{1+2s+s^2}$ with a unit-step $R(s)=\frac{1}{s}$ as an input. Let C(s) be the corresponding output. The time taken by the system output c(t) to reach 94% of its steady-state value $\lim_{t \to \infty }c(t)$, rounded off to two decimal places, is
explanation: Question 8  Explanation: $\begin{aligned} G(s)&=\frac{1}{s^{2}+2 s+1}=\frac{1}{(s+1)^{2}} \\ R(s)&=\frac{1}{s} \\ \alpha (s)&=G(s) R(s)=\frac{1}{s(s+1)^{2}} \end{aligned}$ Using partial fraction expansion, we get, $ \begin{aligned} C(s) & =\frac{A}{s}+\frac{B}{(s+1)}+\frac{C}{(s+1)^{2}} \\ A\left(s^{2}+2 s+1\right)&+B\left(s^{2}+s\right)+C s=1 \\ A&=1 \\ A+B & =0 \Rightarrow B=-1 \\ 2 A+B+C & =0 \Rightarrow C=-1 \\ \therefore \quad C(s) & =\frac{1}{s}-\frac{1}{(s+1)}-\frac{1}{(s+1)^{2}} \\ \text{and}\quad c(t) & =\left(1-e^{-t}-t e^{-t}\right) u(t) \\ \lim _{t \rightarrow \infty} c(t) & =1 \end{aligned}$ In order to reach 94 % of its steady-state value, $ \left(1-e^{-t}-t e^{-t}\right)=0.94$ By trial and error, we get, $ t \approx 4.50 \mathrm{sec}$
subject: Control Systems

question: For the unity feedback control system shown in the figure, the open-loop transfer function G(s) is given as $G(s)=\frac{2}{s(s+1)}$ . The steady state error $e_{ss}$ due to a unit step input is
explanation: Question 10  Explanation: $\begin{aligned} E(s) &=\frac{R(s)}{1+G(s) H(s)} \\ R(s) &=\frac{1}{s} ; G(s)=\frac{2}{s(s+1)}; \\ H(s) &=1 \\ E(s) &=\frac{\frac{1}{s}}{1+\frac{s}{s(s+1)}}=\frac{s+1}{s^{2}+s+2} \\ e_{s s} &=\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} s E(s) \\ &=\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} \frac{s(s+1)}{s^{2}+s+2} \\ e_{s s} &=0 \end{aligned}$
subject: Control Systems

question: In the feedback system shown below $G(s)=\frac{1}{(s^{2}+2s)}$. The step response of the closed-loop system should have minimum settling time and have no overshoot. The required value of gain k to achieve this is ________
explanation: Question 11  Explanation: $\begin{aligned} G(s)&=\frac{1}{s^{2}+2 s} \\ \frac{Y(s)}{R(s)}&=\frac{\frac{K}{s^{2}+2 s}}{1+\frac{K}{s^{2}+2 s}}=\frac{K}{s^{2}+2 s+K} \end{aligned}$ Minimum settling time and no overshoot implies critical damping i.e. $ \begin{aligned} \xi &=1 \\ \omega_{n} &=\sqrt{K} \\ \therefore \quad 2 \times \xi \cdot \omega_{n} &=2 \\ \omega_{n} &=1 \\ \Rightarrow \quad \sqrt{K} &=1 \text { or } K=1 \end{aligned}$
subject: Control Systems

question: The response of the system $G(s)=\frac{s-2}{(s+1)(s+3)}$ to the unit step input u(t) is y(t). The value of $\frac{dy}{dt}$ at t=$0^{+}$ is _________
explanation: Question 12  Explanation: $\begin{aligned} L\left(\frac{d y}{d t}\right) &=(s Y(s)-y(0)) \\ Y(s) &=G(s) \times \frac{1}{s}=\frac{s-2}{s(s+1)(s+3)} \\ y(0)&=\lim _{s \rightarrow \infty} s Y(s) \\ \text{(Applying } & \text{initial value theorem) } \\ &=\lim _{s \rightarrow \infty} \frac{s-2}{(s+1)(s+3)} \\ &=\frac{\left(1-\frac{2}{s}\right)}{s\left(1+\frac{1}{s}\right)\left(1+\frac{3}{s}\right)} \\ y(0)&=0 \\ L\left(\frac{d y}{d t}\right) &=s Y(s)=\frac{s \times(s-2)}{s(s+1)(s+3)} \\ &=\frac{s-2}{(s+1)(s+3)} \\ \left.\frac{d y}{d t}\right|_{t=0} &=\lim _{s \rightarrow \infty} s L\left(\frac{d y}{d t}\right) \\ &=\lim _{s \rightarrow \infty} \frac{s \times(s-2)}{(s+1)(s+3)}\\ &=\frac{\left(1-\frac{2}{s}\right)}{\left(1+\frac{1}{s}\right)\left(1+\frac{3}{s}\right)}=1 \end{aligned}$
subject: Control Systems

question: The open-loop transfer function of a unity-feedback control system is given by $G(s)=\frac{K}{s(s+2)}$ For the peak overshoot of the closed-loop system to a unit step input to be 10%, the value of K is____________
explanation: Question 13  Explanation: $G(s)=\frac{K}{s(s+2)} ; H(s)=1 $ Characteristic equation $=1+G(s) H(s)=0 $ $ \begin{aligned} 1+\frac{K}{s(s+2)} &=0 \\ s^{2}+2 s+K &=0 \Rightarrow \omega_{n}=\sqrt{K} \\ 2 \xi \omega_{n} &=2 ; \xi=\frac{1}{\sqrt{K}} \\ M_{p}&=e^{-\pi\xi/\sqrt{1-\xi^{2}}}-0.1\\ -\frac{\pi \xi}{\sqrt{1-\xi^{2}}} &=\ln (0.1) \\ \Rightarrow \quad\frac{\pi \xi}{\sqrt{1-\xi^{2}}} &=2.3 \\ \pi^{2} \xi^{2} &=(2.3)^{2}\left(1-\xi^{2}\right) \\ 15.16 \xi^{2} &=(2.3)^{2} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \xi&=0.59 \\ \Rightarrow \quad \text{Also}, \quad K&=\frac{1}{\xi^{2}}=2.8 \end{aligned}$
subject: Control Systems

question: The output of a standard second-order system for a unit step input is given as $y(t)=1-\frac{2}{\sqrt{3}}e^{-t}cos(\sqrt{3}t-\frac{\pi }{6})$. The transfer function of the system is
explanation: Question 14  Explanation: The output of a second order system for unit step input $ y(t)=1-\frac{e^{-\xi \omega_{n} t}}{\sqrt{1-\xi^{2}}} \sin \left(\omega_{d} t-\theta\right) \qquad\ldots(i)$ From given data $ \begin{aligned} y(t)&=1-\frac{2}{\sqrt{3}} e^{-t} \cos \left(\sqrt{3} t-\frac{\pi}{6}\right)\\ \therefore \quad \alpha&=\xi \omega_{n}=1 \\ \text{and }\quad \omega_{d}&=\sqrt{3} \\ \omega_{n}&=\sqrt{\alpha^{2}+\omega_{d}^{2}}=2 \\ \xi&=\frac{1}{2} \end{aligned}$ Therefore, the transfer function $ T(s)=\frac{\omega_{n}^{2}}{s^{2}+2 \xi \omega_{n} s+\omega_{n}^{2}}=\frac{4}{s^{2}+2 s+4}$
subject: Control Systems

question: A unity negative feedback system has an open-loop transfer function $G(s)=\frac{K}{s(s+10)}$. The gain for the system to have a damping ratio of 0.25 is ________.
explanation: Question 15  Explanation: $T(s)=\frac{G(s)}{1+G(s) H(s)}=\frac{K}{s^{2}+10 s+K} $ Comparing with standard second order transfer  function $ \begin{aligned} T(s)&=\frac{\omega_{n}^{2}}{s^{2}+2 \xi \omega_{n} s+\omega_{n}^{2}}\\ \text{We have, }\omega_{n}^{2}&=K \\ \text{and }\quad 2 \xi \omega_{n}&=10 \\ \because \quad \xi&=0.25 \quad (given)\\ \therefore \quad \omega_{n}&=\frac{10}{2 \times 0.25}=20 \\ \text{and }\quad k&=\omega_{n}^{2}=(20)^{2}=400 \end{aligned}$
subject: Control Systems

question: The characteristic equation of a unity negative feedback system is $1 + KG(s) = 0$. The open loop transfer function G(s) has one pole at 0 and two poles at -1. The root locus of the system for varying K is shown in the figure. The constant damping ratio line  for $\xi= 0.5$, intersects the root locus at point A. The distance from the origin to point A is given as 0.5. The value of K at point A is ____.
explanation: Question 16  Explanation: According to the question $ G(s) H(s)=\frac{K}{s(s+1)^{2}} \qquad \ldots(i)$ The damping ratio is given as $\xi=0.5$ $ \therefore \quad \theta=\cos ^{-1} \xi=60^{\circ}$ Let the co-ordinates of point 'A' is (-a+jb) where, $\cos 60^{\circ}=\frac{O B}{O A} \qquad \ldots(ii)$ Also, $\quad O A=0.5 $ (Given) $ \therefore O B=0.25$ Similarly, $ \begin{array}{l} \sin 60^{\circ}=\frac{B A}{O A} \qquad \ldots(iii)\\ \therefore \quad B A=j b=0.433 j \end{array}$ Hence, co-ordinates of $A = -0.25 + 0.43j$ $ \therefore $ The value of system gain K can be obtained as $ |G(s) H(s)|=1\qquad \ldots(iv)$ From (i) and (iv) we get $s=-0.25+j 4.33 $ $ K=0.37$
subject: Control Systems

question: A system described by a linear, constant coefficient, ordinary, first order differential equation has an exact solution given by y(t) for t > 0, when the forcing function is x(t) and the initial condition is y(0). If one wishes to modify the system so that the solution becomes -2y(t) for t > 0, we need to
explanation: Question 20  Explanation: $\frac{d y(t)}{d t}+k y(t)=x(t) $ Taking Laplace transform of both sides, we have $ s Y(s)-y(0)+k Y(s)=X(s) $ $ Y(s)[s+k]=X(s)+y(0) $ $ \Rightarrow Y(s)=\frac{X(s)}{s+k}+\frac{y(0)}{s+k} $ Taking inverse Laplace transform, we have $ y(t)=e^{-k t} x(t)+y(0) e^{-k t} $ So if we want -2y(t) as a solution both x(t) and  y(0) has to be multiplied by -2; hence change x(t) by -2x(t) and y(0) by -2y(0).
subject: Control Systems

question: The open-loop transfer function of a dc motor is given as $\frac{w\left ( s \right )}{V_{a}\left ( s \right )}= \frac{10}{1+10s}$. When connected in feedback as shown below, the approximate value of $K_{a}$ that will reduce the time constant of the closed loop system by one hundred times as compared to that of the open-loop system is
explanation: Question 21  Explanation: $\begin{aligned} \frac{\omega(s)}{V_{a}(s)} &=\frac{10}{1+10 s} \\ 1+T s &=1+10 s \\ T s &=10 s \\ \therefore \quad T &=10\\ T^{\prime}=& \frac{T}{100}=\frac{10}{100}=\frac{1}{10} \\ \frac{\omega(s)}{R(s)}=& \frac{K_{a} \times \frac{10}{1+10 s}}{1+K_{a} \frac{10}{1+10 s}} \\ \frac{\omega(s)}{R(s)}&=\frac{10 K_{a}}{1+10 s+10 K_{a}}=\frac{10 K_{a}}{\left(1+10 K_{a}\right)+10s} \\ \frac{\omega(s)}{R(s)}&=\frac{10k_{a}}{\left(1+10 K_{a}\right)\begin{bmatrix}1+\frac{10 s}{1+10 K_{a}}\end{bmatrix}} \\ T^{\prime}&=\frac{10}{1+10K_{a}}=\frac{1}{10}\\ 1+10 K_{a}&=100 \\ 10 K_{a}&=99 \\ K_{a}&=9.9 \\ K_{a} &\cong 10 \end{aligned}$
subject: Control Systems

question: The differential equation $100\frac{d^{2}y}{dt^{2}}-20\frac{dy}{dt}+y=x(t)$ describes a system with an in put x(t) and an output y(t). The system, which is initially relaxed, is excited by a unit step input. The output y(t) can be represented by the waveform
explanation: Question 22  Explanation: $100 \frac{d^{2} y}{d t^{2}}-20 \frac{d y}{d t}+y=x(t)$ Taking Laplace transform of both sides $ 100 s^{2} Y(s)-20 s Y(s)+Y(s)=\frac{X(s)}{s}$ $ \Rightarrow \frac{Y(s)}{X(s)}=\frac{1 / s}{\left(100 s^{2}-20 s+1\right)}=\frac{1}{s(10 s-1)^{2}} $ Poles are at $s=\frac{1}{10}, \frac{1}{10}, 0 $ As poles are on the right-hand side of s-plane so given system is unstable system. Only option (A) represents unstable system.

question:
A linear, time - invariant, causal continuous time system has a rational transfer
function with simple poles at s =- 2 and s =- 4 and one simple zero at s =- 1
. A unit step u(t) is applied at the input of the system. At steady state, the
output has constant value of 1. The impulse response of this system is
explanation: Question 25  Explanation: Transfer functions can be written as, $ \begin{aligned} H(s)&=\frac{K(s+1)}{(s+2)(s+4)} \\ \text{Input,}\quad R(s)&=\frac{1}{s}\\ C(s)&=R(s) H(s) \\ \text{Given:} \quad \lim _{s \rightarrow 0} s C(s)&=1 \\ \text{or,} \quad\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} \frac{s \cdot K(s+1)}{s(s+2)(s+4)}&=1 \\ \text{Or }\quad \frac{K}{8}&=1 \\ \Rightarrow \quad K &=8 \\ H(s) &=\frac{8(s+1)}{(s+2)(s+4)} \\ &=-\frac{4}{s+2}+\frac{12}{s+4} \\ h(t) &=\left(-4 e^{-2 t}+12 e^{-4 t}\right) u(t) \end{aligned}$ Which is also the required impulse response of the system.

question: The transfer function of a plant is $T(s)=\frac{5}{(s+5)(s^{2}+s+1)}$ The second-order approximation of T(s)  using dominant pole concept is
explanation: Question 27  Explanation: In dominant pole concept, the factor that has to be eliminated should be in time constant form. $ \begin{aligned} \frac{5}{(s+5)\left(s^{2}+s+1\right)}=& \frac{5}{5\left(1+\frac{s}{5}\right)\left(s^{2}+s+1\right)} \\ =& \frac{1}{s^{2}+s+1} \end{aligned}$

question: The unit impulse response of a system is $h(t) =  e^{-t},t\geq 0$. For this system the steady-state value of the output for unit step input is equal to
explanation: Question 28  Explanation: $\begin{aligned} h(t) &=e^{-t} \\ H(s) &=\frac{1}{s+1} \\ R(s) &=\frac{1}{s} \\ \text { Output } &=H(s) \cdot R(s)=\frac{1}{(s+1)} \cdot \frac{1}{s} \\ \frac{1}{s(s+1)} &=\frac{A}{s}+\frac{B}{s+1} \\ 1 &=A(s+1)+B s \\ s &=0,1=A \\ s &=-1,1=-B \\ \therefore \quad \text{ Output }&=\frac{1}{s}-\frac{1}{s+1} \\ & =\left(1-e^{-t}\right) u(t) \end{aligned} $ When $t=\infty$ at steady state. Output = 1

question:
A ramp input applied to an unity feedback system results in 5% steady state
error. The type number and zero frequency gain of the system are respectively
explanation: Question 30  Explanation: $\begin{aligned} e_{s s} &=\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} s E(s), R(s)=\frac{1}{s^{2}} \\ &=\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} s \frac{R(s)}{1+G(s)} \\ &=\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} \frac{1}{s+s G(s)}=\text { finite (given) } \\ K_{v} &=\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} s G(s) \\ e_{s s} &=\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} \frac{1}{s G(s)}=\text { finite }=5 \%=\frac{1}{20} \\ \therefore \quad K &=20 \end{aligned} $ $ K_{v}$ is finite for type 1 system having ramp input.

question:
A causal system having the transfer function H(s)=1/(s+2) is excited with
10u(t). The time at which the output reaches 99% of its steady state value is
explanation: Question 33  Explanation: $\begin{aligned} H(s) &=\frac{1}{s+2} \\ r(t) &=10 u(t) \\ R(s) &=\frac{10}{s} \\ C(s) &=H(s) \cdot R(s)=\frac{1}{s+2} \cdot \frac{10}{s} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{10}{s(s+2)} &=\frac{A}{s}+\frac{B}{s+2} \\ 10 &=A(s+2)+B s \\ s &=0,10=2 A \\ \Rightarrow \quad A &=5 \\ s &=-2,10=-2 B \\ \Rightarrow \quad B &=-5 \\ \therefore \quad C(s) &=\frac{5}{s}-\frac{5}{s+2} \\ c(t) &=5\begin{bmatrix}1-e^{2 t}\end{bmatrix} u(t) \end{aligned}$ Steady state value when t=0 is 5.99% of steady state value reaches at $ \begin{aligned} & 5\begin{bmatrix}1-e^{2 t}\end{bmatrix}=0.99 \times 5 \\ \Rightarrow \quad & 1-e^{-2 t}=0.99 \\ & e^{2 t}=0.1 \\ \Rightarrow \quad &-2 t=\ln 0.1 \\ \Rightarrow \quad & t=2.3 \mathrm{sec} \end{aligned}$

question: A system described by the following differential equation $\frac{d^{2}y}{dt^{2}}+3\frac{dy}{dt}+2y=x(t)$ is initially at rest. For input x(t)=2u(t), the output y(t) is
explanation: Question 34  Explanation: $\begin{aligned} \frac{d^{2} y}{d t^{2}}+\frac{3 d y}{d t}+2 y &=X(t) \\ s^{2} Y(s)+3 s Y(s)+2 Y(s) &=X(s) \\ x(t) &=2 u(t) \\ X(s) &=\frac{2}{s} \\ \therefore \quad\left(s^{2}+3 s+2\right) Y(s) &=\frac{2}{s} \\ r(s) &=\frac{2}{s(s+2)(s+1)} \\ \frac{2}{s(s+2)(s+1)} &=\frac{A}{s}+\frac{B}{s+2}+\frac{C}{s+1} \end{aligned}$ $ \begin{aligned} 2&=A(s+2)(s+1)+B s(s+1)+C(s+2) s \\ s&=0,2=2 A \Rightarrow A=1 \\ s&=-1,2=-C \Rightarrow C=-2 \\ s&=-2,2=2 B \Rightarrow B=1 \\ Y(s)&=\frac{1}{s}+\frac{1}{s+2}-\frac{2}{s+1} \\ y(t)&=(1+e^{-2 t}-2 e^{-t}) u(t)  \end{aligned}$

question: A second-order system has the transfer function $\frac{C(s)}{R(s)}=\frac{4}{s^{2}+4s+4}$. With r(t) as the unit-step function, the response c(t) of the system is represented by
explanation: Question 35  Explanation: $\begin{aligned} \frac{C(s)}{R(s)} &=\frac{4}{s^{2}+4 s+4} \\ 2 \xi(0) &=4, \omega_{n}=2 \\ \therefore \quad \xi &=1 \quad \text { (Critical damping) } \\ t_{s} &=\frac{4}{\xi \omega_{n}}=\frac{4}{1 \times 2}=2 \end{aligned}$

question: Consider a system with the transfer function $G(s)=\frac{s+6}{ks^{2}+s+6}$. Its damping ratio will be 0.5 when the value of k is
explanation: Question 37  Explanation: $\begin{array}{l} \frac{s+6}{k\left(s^{2}+\frac{s}{k}+\frac{6}{k}\right)} \\ \text { Comparing with } s^{2}+2 \xi \omega_{n}+\omega_{n}^{2} \\ \begin{aligned} \omega_{n}&=\sqrt{\frac{6}{k}} \\ 2 \xi \omega_{n}&=\frac{1}{k} \\ 2 \times 0.5 \times \sqrt{\frac{6}{k}}&=\frac{1}{k} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \frac{6}{k}&=\frac{1}{k^{2}} \\ k&=\frac{1}{6} \end{aligned} \end{array}$

question:

explanation: Question 38  Explanation: $\begin{aligned} \mathrm{CLTF} &=\frac{G(s)}{1+G(s) H(s)}=\frac{s+4}{s^{2}+7 s+13} \\ \frac{1+G(s) H(s)}{G(s)} &=\frac{s^{2}+7 s+13}{s+4} \end{aligned} $ $ H(s)=1$ for unity feedback. $ \begin{aligned} \frac{1}{G(s)} &=\frac{s^{2}+7 s+13}{s+4}-1 \\ \frac{1}{G(s)} &=\frac{s^{2}+6 s+9}{s+4} \\ \therefore \quad G(s) &=\frac{s+4}{s^{2}+6 s+9} \\ \text { For D.C. } \quad s&=0\\ \therefore \quad G(s) &=\text{open loop gain} \\ &=\frac{4}{9} \end{aligned}$

question: A machine has a 32-bit architecture with 1-word long instructions. It has 24 registers and supports an instruction set of size 40. Each instruction has five distinct fields, namely opcode, two source register identifiers, one destination register identifier, and an immediate value. Assuming that the immediate operand is an unsigned integer, its maximum value is ______.
explanation:
Question 1  Explanation: Given 32-bit architecture $\{1$ word long instructions $\}$ $
1 \text { word }=32 \text {-bits }
$ Number of registers $=24$, bits required $\Rightarrow 2^{n}=24$ $
n=\log _{2}(24)
$ $
\therefore \quad n=5 \text {-bits }
$ Number instructions $=40$ $\therefore$ Opcode bits would be $2^{n}=40$ $\therefore \quad n=\log _{2}(40)$ $
n=6 \text {-bits }
$ Each register field requires 5 -bits. Instruction format would be $\therefore$ Immediate value bits $=32-(6+5+5+5)=32-21=11$-bits The range of unsigned values $=0$ to $2^{n}-1$ $
=0 \text { to } 2^{11}-1=0 \text { to }(2048-1)=0 \text { to } 2047
$ $\therefore$ Maximum unsigned integer $=2047$

explanation: Question 7  Explanation: LXI SP, EFFFH CALL 3000 H $ \Rightarrow \quad \text { PUSH }+\text { JMP } \quad \mathrm{SP} \rightarrow \mathrm{SP}-2 $ $ \Rightarrow \quad \mathrm{SP}=\mathrm{EFFDH} $ $ \begin{array}{ll}\\ 3000 \mathrm{H}: & \mathrm{LXIH}, 3 \mathrm{CF} 4 \mathrm{H} \\ & \mathrm{HL} \leftarrow 3 \mathrm{CF} 4 \\ \text { PUSHPSW } & \mathrm{SP} \leftarrow \mathrm{SP}-2=\mathrm{EFFBH} \\ \text { SPHL } & \mathrm{SP} \leftarrow 3 \mathrm{CF} 4 \\ \text { POP PSW } & \mathrm{SP} \leftarrow \mathrm{SP}+2=3 \mathrm{CF} 6 \\ \text { RET } & \mathrm{RET}=\mathrm{POP}+\mathrm{JMP} \text { i.e. } \\ & \mathrm{SP} \leftarrow \mathrm{SP}+2 \\ & \mathrm{SP} \leftarrow 3 \mathrm{CF} 8 \mathrm{H}\end{array}$

explanation:

\begin{aligned}

&\downarrow \\
&\text{Sign flag  }=0 \text{ (plus)}
